## On How to Legally Bribe Governments (The Technical Version)

The legal setup is more important than the money, which is saying something when there's `{python} format_billions(TREATY_ANNUAL_FUNDING)` involved.

You're essentially bribing governments to redirect military spending. Except instead of paying politicians under the table (illegal, messy, tends to end in prison), you're paying voters to vote for politicians who support the treaty (legal, transparent, ends in democratic mandate).

This requires following international law, securities regulations, and election laws across 195 countries without violating a single rule in any of them.

The design is **bulletproof and legal.** Which is fortunate, because the alternative is "brilliant and illegal," which is just another way of saying "stupid."

## On How to Sell Investment Products Without Going to Prison

**[VICTORY Bonds](./economics.qmd)** are securities. Tokens might be securities. The SEC has opinions about both.

The strategy: be so obviously compliant that regulators get bored trying to find violations.

### The Three-Tier Legal Strategy

**Tier 1: Rich People (Accredited Investors)**

Start by raising money from people who are legally allowed to make terrible investment decisions because they're rich enough to survive them.

Use standard private placement rules (Reg D 506(c) in the US, equivalents elsewhere). This provides a solid financial base while following every securities law on the books.

**Tier 2: Regular People (Utility Tokens)**

Regular people earn utility tokens for actions like voting, participating in trials, or contributing to the platform. These start as utility points, not investments.

They only become valuable AFTER the treaty passes and the system generates revenue. This timing [avoids the Howey Test securities law problems](./references.qmd#howey-test-securities) because there's no "expectation of profit from the efforts of others" at the time of distribution.

**Tier 3: Marketing (No Bullshit Allowed)**

Focus on what the project actually does, not get-rich-quick promises. Be painfully clear about risks.

The marketing pitch is: "Help us redirect military spending to cure disease. If it works, you might make money. If it doesn't, you definitely won't. Invest accordingly."

Regulators love honesty. Mostly because they see so little of it.
